docs.lead_paragraph: Thirty-six companies have decided to join forces in a push to extend health insurance to all Americans, The Los Angeles Times reported today.

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-16 Sarkozy Wins as French Remain With the Right Nicholas Sarkozy was elected president in France, trouncing his Socialist opponent and ensuring that the French right stays in power for another five years. Mr. Sarkozy promised a break with the past, a new style of leadership and a renewal of relations with the United States and the rest of Europe. A1 Candidate Withdraws in Turkey A Turkish presidential candidate with a background in Islamic politics withdrew his candidacy, ending a struggle that has sharply divided Turkish society and reshaped the political landscape. A12 Throngs Cheer Pakistani Judge The chief justice of Pakistan's supreme court, suspended by the government after he investigated some of its practices, received an emotional welcome from thousands of supporters. A3 Clash Near U.N. School in Gaza A clash outside a United Nations-run school in Gaza left one Palestinian dead and six wounded, witnesses and Palestinian security officials said. The chief of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency in Gaza said two of those wounded were schoolchildren, ages 14 and 9. A6 World Bank Inquest Unfinished The World Bank committee investigating misconduct charges against Paul D. Wolfowitz, the bank president, failed to complete its review on schedule, but bank officials said the panel would eventually find that he violated bank rules barring conflicts of interest. A16 NATIONAL A17-19 Whistleblower's Warnings About Loans Were Ignored Early warnings made by a Department of Education researcher to stop the hemorrhage of taxpayers' money to student lending companies were rebuked, records show. The researcher's story opened a window onto how the Bush administration repeatedly resisted calls to improve oversight of the $85 billion student loan industry. A1 Tactics of Insurers Are Faulted Insurance companies have used improper hard-sell tactics to persuade Medicare recipients to sign up for private health plans, known as Medicare Advantage plans, that cost the government far more than the traditional Medicare program, federal and state officials and consumer advocates say.A1 California's Sway in Primaries In the months since California and about 20 other states changed the dates of their primaries, major presidential campaigns have sought to measure how the early nominating contests will shape their tactical calculations. But California is likely to wield additional clout this time around, altering the dialogue of the contest to issues that have historically drawn little attention. A19 Tornado's Toll in Kansas In the wake of the tornado, over a mile wide, that devastated Greensburg, Kan., are eight confirmed deaths, many injuries and 80 square blocks of rubble. The scope of destruction has also shocked the remaining population and emergency officials. A17 NEW YORK/REGION B1-5 Officers' Digital Cameras Strengthen Abuse Cases Providing digital cameras to police officers is revolutionizing the prosecution of domestic violence in New York City, according to district attorneys, advocates and forensic technicians. B1 Learning the Parent's Language Many immigrants who came to the United States as children or who were born here to immigrant parents are taking foreign languages in increasing numbers in a quest to become fully literate in their mother tongue. B1 SPORTSMONDAY D1-8 Clemens Returns to Yankees Roger Clemens, the 44-year-old right-hander who pitched for the Yankees from 1999 to 2003, returns to the team in a deal that was informally announced during a Yankees/Seattle Mariners match up. A1 BUSINESS DAY C1-12 Investors Aid the Pentagon The Defense Department is using some of the nation's top technology investors to help it find innovations from tiny start-up companies.The Defense Venture Catalyst Initiative, or DeVenCi for short, consists of meetings where venture capitalists suggest solutions culled from technology start-ups. C1 Business Digest C2 OBITUARIES B6 Alvin Batiste A clarinetist who toured wih Ray Charles and recorded with Branford Marsalis, he was 74. B6 EDITORIAL A20-21 Editorials: The soft bigotry of Iraq; after the pet food contamination; still best in show; Lawrence Downes on New Orleans. Column: Nicholas D. Kristof. Bridge E7 Crossword E2 Metro Diary B2 TV Listings E9 Weather B7

docs.lead_paragraph: IN spite of record increases in state aid for next school year, most districts in Westchester and other New York City suburbs have proposed property tax increases well above the rate of inflation. District officials say they are handcuffed by big annual increases in teachers’ salaries and the rising cost of pensions, health insurance and energy.
